metadata.title: French Greetings for Beginners
metadata.description: Learning basic French greetings to start a new linguistic adventure!

curriculum.lesson_topic: Daily Life in France: A Beginner's Guide

sub_topics.sub_topic: Meeting People: Basic Greetings and Introductions
sub_topics.description: Learn how to greet people politely and introduce yourself in French, including basic phrases for everyday situations.

sub_topics.sub_topic: Ordering Food and Drinks in a Café
sub_topics.description: Learn how to order common food and beverage items in a French café, understand the menu, and ask for the bill.

sub_topics.sub_topic: Asking for Directions and Getting Around Town
sub_topics.description: Learn how to ask for and understand directions in French, enabling you to navigate a French city or town effectively.
Learn how to buy groceries, ask for quantities, and understand basic shopping vocabulary, making it easier to shop in French markets or supermarkets.

sub_topics.sub_topic: Talking About Your Daily Routine and Hobbies
sub_topics.description: Learn how to describe your daily activities and hobbies in French, enabling you to share personal information and engage in simple conversations about your life.

flashcards.example: Au revoir, et à la prochaine fois !

exercises.explanation: 'Allez' is the correct form of the verb 'aller' to use with 'vous' in this context. 'Avoir', 'être' and 'faire' do not fit the structure of the common greeting 'Comment allez-vous ?'.
'Je' is the correct subject pronoun to use in this sentence to say 'I am fine, thank you.' The other pronouns do not fit the response.

exercises.sentence: En France, on se serre la main pour ___ bonjour à quelqu'un.
exercises.explanation: 'Dire' means 'to say,' which is what you do when you greet someone. 'Parler' (to speak), 'chanter' (to sing), and 'écrire' (to write) don't make sense in this context.

exercises.sentence: Le matin, je dis toujours '___ jour' à mes voisins.
exercises.explanation: 'Bon' is used to form the greeting 'Bonjour' (good day). 'Mauvais', 'grand', and 'petit' do not form common greetings.

exercises.sentence: Quand on quitte un ami, on dit souvent '___ revoir'.
exercises.explanation: 'À' is the correct preposition to use in the phrase 'À revoir', meaning 'goodbye'. The other prepositions do not create a standard farewell phrase.

simulation.title: Café Bonjour: A French Greeting Adventure
simulation.setting: Two travelers, Alice and Bob, meet at a charming café in Paris. Alice is just starting to learn French, and Bob, a seasoned traveler, helps her practice basic greetings.

content.speaker: Narrator
content.target_language_text: Alice arrive au café, un peu nerveuse.
content.phonetics: a.lis a.ʁiv o ka.fe, œ̃ pø nɛʁ.vøz.
content.base_language_translation: Alice arrives at the café, a bit nervous.

content.speaker: Bob
content.target_language_text: Bonjour Alice! Je m'appelle Bob. Enchanté!
content.phonetics: bɔ̃.ʒuʁ a.lis! ʒə ma.pɛl bɔb. ɑ̃.ʃɑ̃.te!
content.base_language_translation: Hello Alice! My name is Bob. Nice to meet you!

content.speaker: Alice
content.base_language_translation: Nice to meet you, Bob! How are you?

content.speaker: Bob
content.base_language_translation: Very well, thank you. And you?

content.speaker: Alice
content.target_language_text: Bien, merci. Un café, s'il vous plaît.
content.phonetics: bjɛ̃, mɛʁ.si. œ̃ ka.fe, sil vu ple.
content.base_language_translation: Well, thank you. A coffee, please.

content.speaker: Bob
content.base_language_translation: Excuse me, do you speak French?

content.speaker: Alice
content.base_language_translation: A little! I am a beginner.

content.speaker: Bob
content.target_language_text: Pas de problème! Au revoir pour l'instant!
content.phonetics: pa də pʁɔ.blɛm! o ʁə.vwaʁ puʁ lɛ̃s.tɑ̃!
